com.stormpath.sdk.directory

Class Directories

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.stormpath.sdk.directory.Directories

  • public final class Directories
extends Object
    Static utility/helper methods for working with Directory resources. Most methods are factory methods used for forming Directory-specific fluent DSL queries. For example: 
     Directories.where(Directories.name().containsIgnoreCase("Foo"))
     .and(Directories.status().eq(DirectoryStatus.ENABLED))
     .orderByName().descending()
     .withAccounts(10, 10)
     .offsetBy(50)
     .limitTo(25));
    or, if using static imports: 
     import static com.stormpath.sdk.directory.Directories.*;

 ...

 where(name().containsIgnoreCase("Foo"))
     .and(status().eq(DirectoryStatus.ENABLED))
     .orderByName().descending()
     .withAccounts(10, 10)
     .offsetBy(50)
     .limitTo(25));
    Since:
    0.8

      • options

        public static DirectoryOptions options()
        Returns a new DirectoryOptions instance, used to customize how one or more Directory(ies) are retrieved.
        Returns:
        a new DirectoryOptions instance, used to customize how one or more Directory(ies) are retrieved.

      • criteria

        public static DirectoryCriteria criteria()
        Returns a new DirectoryCriteria instance to use to formulate a Directory query.

        Note that it is usually more common to use the where method instead of this one as the where method usually lends to better readability. For example: 

         Directories.criteria().add(Directories.name().eqIgnoreCase("Foo"))...
        versus: 
         Directories.where(Directories.name().eqIgnoreCase("Foo"))...
        or when using static imports: 
         where(name().eqIgnoreCase("Foo"))...
        While all three statements are equivalent, the second and third examples are shorter and probably more readable.
        Returns:
        a new DirectoryCriteria instance to use to formulate a Directory query.

      • where

        public static DirectoryCriteria where(Criterion criterion)
        Creates a new DirectoryCriteria instance using the specified criterion as the first query condition.
        Returns:
        a new DirectoryCriteria instance using the specified criterion as the first query condition.

      • name

        public static StringExpressionFactory name()
        Creates a new StringExpressionFactory instance reflecting the Directory name property, to be used to construct a name Criterion when building an DirectoryCriteria query. For example: 
         Directories.where(Directories.name().startsWithIgnoreCase("foo");
        The above example invokes the returned factory's startsWithIgnoreCase("foo") method. This produces a name-specific Criterion which is added to the criteria query (via the where method). For example, the following code is equivalent: 
         DirectoryCriteria criteria = Directories.criteria();
 StringExpressionFactory nameExpressionFactory = Directories.name();
 Criterion nameStartsWithFoo = nameExpressionFactory.startsWithIgnoreCase("foo");
 criteria.add(nameStartsWithFoo);
        The first code example is clearly more succinct and readable.
        Returns:
        a new name-specific StringExpressionFactory instance, to be used to construct a criterion when building an DirectoryCriteria query.

      • description

        public static StringExpressionFactory description()
        Creates a new StringExpressionFactory instance reflecting the Directory description property, to be used to construct a description Criterion when building an DirectoryCriteria query. For example: 
         Directories.where(Directories.description().startsWithIgnoreCase("foo");
        The above example invokes the returned factory's startsWithIgnoreCase("foo") method. This produces a description-specific Criterion which is added to the criteria query (via the where method). For example, the following code is equivalent: 
         DirectoryCriteria criteria = Directories.criteria();
 StringExpressionFactory descriptionExpressionFactory = Directories.description();
 Criterion descriptionStartsWithFoo = descriptionExpressionFactory.startsWithIgnoreCase("foo");
 criteria.add(descriptionStartsWithFoo);
        The first code example is clearly more succinct and readable.
        Returns:
        a new description-specific StringExpressionFactory instance, to be used to construct a criterion when building an DirectoryCriteria query.

      • status

        public static EqualsExpressionFactory status()
        Creates a new EqualsExpressionFactory instance reflecting the Directory status property, to be used to construct a status Criterion when building an DirectoryCriteria query. For example: 
         Directories.where(Directories.status().eq(DirectoryStatus.ENABLED);
        The above example invokes the returned factory's eq() method. This produces a status-specific Criterion which is added to the criteria query (via the where method). For example, the following code is equivalent: 
         DirectoryCriteria criteria = Directories.criteria();
 StringExpressionFactory statusExpressionFactory = Directories.status();
 Criterion statusEqualsEnabled = statusExpressionFactory.eq(DirectoryStatus.ENABLED);
 criteria.add(statusEqualsEnabled);
        The first code example is clearly more succinct and readable.
        Returns:
        a new status-specific StringExpressionFactory instance, to be used to construct a criterion when building an DirectoryCriteria query.

      • newCreateRequestFor

        public static CreateDirectoryRequestBuilder newCreateRequestFor(Directory directory)
